_comment: Core EPAs for Entering Residency â€” 81 nodes (8 domains + 13 EPAs + 60 subcompetencies). Source: AAMC Core Entrustable Professional Activities for Entering Residency (2014), AAMC Toolkit (2017), WMed/Penn State competency mappings.

competencies.name: Gather a history and perform a physical examination
Prioritize a differential diagnosis following a clinical encounter
Recommend and interpret common diagnostic and screening tests
Enter and discuss orders and prescriptions
Document a clinical encounter in the patient record
Provide an oral presentation of a clinical encounter
Form clinical questions and retrieve evidence to advance patient care
Give or receive a patient handover to transition care responsibility
Collaborate as a member of an interprofessional team
Recognize a patient requiring urgent or emergent care and initiate evaluation and management
Obtain informed consent for tests and/or procedures
Perform general procedures of a physician
Identify system failures and contribute to a culture of safety and improvement

subcompetencies.name: Perform an accurate complete or focused history in a prioritized and organized manner
Perform an accurate complete or focused physical examination in a prioritized and organized manner
Tailor the history and physical examination to the clinical situation and patient context
Integrate scientific foundations of medicine with clinical reasoning to guide information gathering
Demonstrate respect, compassion, and responsiveness to patient needs during the encounter
Integrate and synthesize patient data from history, physical exam, and ancillary studies to formulate an assessment
Develop a prioritized list of potential diagnoses (differential diagnosis)
Select a working diagnosis based on available evidence
Continuously adapt the differential to avoid common errors of clinical reasoning such as premature closure
Recognize limitations in one's own clinical reasoning and seek additional information when needed
Select appropriate diagnostic tests based on the pre-test probability of disease
Interpret results of common diagnostic and screening tests
Apply evidence-based and cost-effective principles to test selection
Recommend age-appropriate and risk-factor-appropriate screening tests
Communicate results and their implications to patients and colleagues
Write safe, indicated, and legible orders in inpatient and ambulatory settings
Write safe and appropriate prescriptions considering drug interactions, allergies, and renal/hepatic function
Discuss the rationale for orders with patients and members of the health care team
Recognize one's own limitations and seek review for unfamiliar orders or prescriptions
Utilize electronic ordering systems and clinical decision support tools appropriately
Provide accurate and focused documentation of a clinical encounter in written or electronic format
Document the evolution of the patient's problems, diagnostic work-up, and therapeutic interventions
Incorporate social and cultural determinants of health into clinical documentation
Incorporate the patient's preferences and shared decision-making into documentation
Produce context-specific documentation appropriate to the setting (e.g., admission note, progress note, discharge summary)
Concisely present a summary of a clinical encounter to members of the health care team
Synthesize information gathered into an accurate assessment of the patient's current condition
Tailor the oral presentation to the audience and clinical context
Clearly articulate a reasoned assessment and plan
Identify key clinical questions arising from patient care
Identify and use appropriate information resources to address clinical questions
Retrieve evidence relevant to clinical questions
Critically appraise the quality and applicability of retrieved evidence
Apply evidence to clinical decision-making and patient care
Use a structured communication framework (e.g., I-PASS, SBAR) for handover
Communicate essential patient information including active and anticipated problems, tasks, and contingency plans
Verify understanding through interactive questioning and closed-loop communication
Ensure continuity of care across transitions between settings, teams, or providers
Demonstrate responsibility and professionalism during transitions of care
Identify the roles, responsibilities, and contributions of interprofessional team members
Communicate effectively with all members of the health care team
Establish and maintain a climate of mutual respect, dignity, and trust with team members
Participate in shared decision-making and collaborative care planning
Reflect on one's own role within the team and how it contributes to patient outcomes
Promptly recognize a patient who requires urgent or emergent care
Initiate evaluation of acutely ill or deteriorating patients
Initiate basic stabilization and management (e.g., ABCs, IV access, oxygen)
Seek help and escalate care appropriately by communicating clinical urgency
Recognize common urgent/emergent conditions (e.g., chest pain, mental status changes, shortness of breath, hypotension, arrhythmias, electrolyte abnormalities)
Explain indications, risks, benefits, and alternatives for proposed tests or procedures in patient-understandable language
Assess the patient's understanding and capacity for decision-making
Elicit and address patient questions and concerns
Document the informed consent process appropriately
Perform basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Perform bag and mask ventilation
Perform venipuncture
Insert an intravenous line
Demonstrate knowledge of indications, contraindications, and complications of core procedures
Recognize system-level factors that contribute to patient safety events and near misses
Report patient safety events and near misses through appropriate institutional channels
Participate in root cause analysis and other quality improvement methods
Propose and contribute to implementation of changes to improve patient safety
Demonstrate a commitment to a culture of safety, including disclosure of errors and non-punitive reporting
